repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - First, Second, and Third Phase
            of the Provincial Health Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First, Second, and Third
            Phase of the Provincial Health Project for Indonesia  were
            as follows: outcome was unsatisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was significant, Bank performance was
            unsatisfactory, and Borrower performance was unsatisfactory.
            Some lessons learned included: when undertaking extensive
            policy reforms in a rapidly changing political and
            institutional environment, challenges and risks posed by
            traditional ways of doing business are likely to be
            formidable. They often are of a political economy nature, as
            well as technical; and both kinds of risks need to be
            recognized and planned for. In Indonesia, reluctance to
            introduce accompanying regulations to new laws was an
            indicator that new institutional arrangements had yet to
            mature; and that government was not yet ready to firm up its
            options for defining new responsibilities. Conventional
            government processes (budget processes, fiduciary controls)
            should be amenable to adjustment, especially when the
            emphasis is on piloting new methods. The purpose of piloting
            is to learn and adapt, which requires some flexibility. All
            three projects were piloting new complex reforms in an
            unsettled environment. All three were closely sequenced,
            offering limited opportunity for transmitting learning from
            one project to another. Projects introducing new
            institutions must be seen as opportunities for learning and
            improving, and sequencing should have that in mind.

docna.cdata!:
Indonesia - First, Second, and Third Phase
            of the Provincial Health Project

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Health Work Force and Services;
            and Third Provincial Health Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Health Work Force and
            Services; and Third Provincial Health Project for Indonesia
            were as follows: outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory,
            the risk to development outcome was substantial, Bank
            performance was moderately satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was also moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: stakeholders welcomed the opportunity to
            conduct bottom-up planning under the project and many
            believed that establishing the capacity to conduct evidence
            based planning was a major achievement of Health Work
            Services (HWS). Participants at the central level felt that
            the Minister of Health (MOH) components will have been
            stronger had there been more concerted efforts on behalf of
            MOH during project preparation. Complex projects like HWS
            require a lot of learning and adaptation, particularly
            during the first years of implementation, and a longer
            implementation period is warranted. Workshop participants at
            all levels agreed that clear objectives and indicators are
            important for guiding project implementation and to keep it
            focused. Central level participants mentioned that the
            objectives of the central components were not well defined.
            The unclear role of the province level at the beginning of
            decentralization contributed to the rather loose description
            of the provincial component of the project. Participants
            confirmed that districts appreciated being invited to
            participate in designing the district component during
            project preparation. Participants agreed that performance
            during implementation was better where the project appraisal
            document (PAD) clearly described the scope of project activities.

repnme.cdata!: Indonesia - Health Workforce and Services Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Health Workforce and Services
            Project will support health sector decentralization in four
            provinces, focusing on sustainable financing, and
            client-centered delivery of health services. Specifically,
            the project will enhance access to care, quality of care,
            and, health outcomes at the district level, while
            strengthening health work-force policy, management, and
            development in a decentralized context. A corollary
            development objective is to empower the Ministry of Health
            (MOH), the Ministry of National Education (MONE), and the
            Indonesian Medical Association (IMA), the three key
            stakeholders in the sector, through assistance to redefine
            their roles and responsibilities, vis-a-vis health
            work-force policy, planning, and management; and, by
            building their institutional capacity towards fulfilling
            policy making, legislation, regulation, quality
            assurance/control, and technical assistance. The project
            will have three components, each applicable to all three
            levels of governance: (1) improved health system
            stewardship, including policy and planning, management and
            system regulation; (2) sustained and expanded health
            services financing and delivery; and, (3) strengthened
            health workforce policy, management and training, including
            enhanced quality of medical education.

repnme.cdata!: Indonesia - Health Workforce and Services Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Health Workforce and Services
            Project will construct hospitals with fewer than 200 beds,
            and renovate existing ones in Indonesia. Some environmental
            impacts include loss or degradation of natural habitat and
            wildlife, disruption of river flow regimes, drainage
            patterns, increase in traffic congestion, decrease in
            receiving water and air quality, and risk associated with
            fiber-concrete building materials containing asbestos. The
            project will adopt mitigation measures in designing
            specifications for hospitals to minimize disruption of
            natural habitat and vegetation, redesign of building layout
            in flood prone areas, restrict work to daylight hours to
            limit noise and dust emissions, prohibit use of building
            materials containing asbestos. The project will also adopt
            proper health procedures during removal and transportation
            of asbestos. Supply of safe water should also be considered
            during project planning and implementation.

display_title.display_title:
Indonesia - Health Workforce and
            Services Project : Environmental Management Plan

            DECENTRALIZED MANAGEMENT OF HEALTH WORK FORCE

repnme.cdata!: Indonesia - Health Workforce and Services Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Health Workforce and Services
            Project will construct hospitals with fewer than 200 beds,
            and renovate existing ones in Indonesia. Some environmental
            impacts include loss or degradation of natural habitat and
            wildlife, disruption of river flow regimes, drainage
            patterns, increase in traffic congestion, decrease in
            receiving water and air quality, and risk associated with
            fiber-concrete building materials containing asbestos. The
            project will adopt mitigation measures in designing
            specifications for hospitals to minimize disruption of
            natural habitat and vegetation, redesign of building layout
            in flood prone areas, restrict work to daylight hours to
            limit noise and dust emissions, prohibit use of building
            materials containing asbestos. The project will also adopt
            proper health procedures during removal and transportation
            of asbestos. Supply of safe water should also be considered
            during project planning and implementation.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Health Workforce and Services
            Project : indigenous peoples plan

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an Indigenous Peoples Plan for
            the Health Workforce and Services Project for Indonesia,
            which improves the health system, expands health service
            delivery, and strengthens the health workforce. This report
            focuses on specific measures to safeguard isolated
            vulnerable peoples, or IVP. The latter are individuals or
            communities including but not limited to indigenous people
            that share similar characteristics such as being outside the
            mainstream of political and economic power, physical
            isolation, language and cultural barriers, or part of an
            ethnic minority. By targeting the welfare of IVP the project
            addresses health care for some of the poorest segments of
            the society. Approaches to developing the capacity of the
            government to collect data on IVPs as a discrete group will
            be incorporated into the project's implementation. The
            project will ensure that measures are incorporated into
            proposals that involve stakeholders in project design and
            implementation, including training for participatory
            planning. The report also advocates that community groups be
            provided an opportunity to give feedback directly to the
            Bank on implementation issues to enhance transparency. It is
            expected that improved transparency and community
            participation will reduce the incidence of
            "unofficial" charges and user fees. Infrastructure
            will be developed as appropriate in remote areas to improve
            access for isolated communities. Options to be considered
            include the construction of more health centers and the use
            of mobile health units. Additionally, the project will
            consider options for increased recruitment and training of
            health workers from IVP communities as well as developing
            culturally appropriate approaches to working with IVP. By
            improving the quality of health care providers, it is
            expected that there will be an opportunity to build trust
            among communities. Lastly, the project will support
            developing culturally appropriate communications materials
            in order to improve the access of IVP to health information;
            option for incorporating traditional beliefs, medicines, and
            health care practices into the training of health care
            workers will be considered.
